raw_text:
Safin plays down Wimbledon hopes
 
 Newly-crowned Australian Open champion Marat Safin has ruled out any chance of winning Wimbledon in the future.
 
 After losing in round one last year, Safin said he had "given up" on Wimbledon and winning his second Grand Slam title has not changed his mind. "I'll play, but with no expectations. I feel like I can't waste my time, my energy on that surface," he said. "Some people, they cannot play on clay. Some people, they cannot play on a hard court. Me, I can't play on grass." However, Safin is hopeful that winning the Australian Open will give him the belief he needs to win more Grand Slam titles. "It's a relief for me. Two grand slams, it's already something. But with this one I worked really hard for it," he said. "Basically, I would love to win a couple more. I think I have a chance if I continue this way.
 
 "If (coach) Peter Lundgren will stick around with me and wants to work with me for a bit longer, I think I can make it." The 25-year-old shocked Pete Sampras in the 2000 US Open final to win his first major title but then lost in two Australian Open finals. Safin admitted he had begun to doubt whether he would win another Grand Slam. "I didn't expect that (to win the 2000 US Open) - it was against Sampras, I wasn't the favourite so I had no pressure whatsoever," he said. "After the first final that I didn't win against Thomas Johansson (in 2002), I couldn't see myself winning the Grand Slams anymore. "I was once in the semi-finals of the French Open, but I didn't believe I can win it. "I just couldn't handle the pressure. You need to believe in yourself, and I didn't."
 
 And after losing the first set 6-1 to Lleyton Hewitt in Sunday's final, Safin said he began to doubt himself again. "I am 25. I'm playing against Hewitt. At least you have to have the opportunity to win it, at least have a chance," he said. "It's like you go there and you lose first set 6-1, then you start to think: 'This is not my day. The way I'm playing is ridiculous.' "But then you start to really be a little bit more selfish and try to find a way out of there. "And I found it. I was like really much I was much happier than in 2000, that's for sure, because I get over it."
llama3.2:1b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon in the future after losing in round one last year. He believes he can no longer afford to waste time and energy on clay courts and instead hopes winning the Australian Open will give him confidence to win more Grand Slam titles.
llama3.2:3b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon due to his struggles on grass courts. He plans to continue playing with no expectations and is hopeful that winning the Australian Open has given him the confidence to win more Grand Slam titles. Safin believes he can make a comeback if he continues his current form and finds the right mental approach, having previously won the US Open in 2000 but losing in two Australian Open finals.
gemma2:2b:
Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon and won't play with expectations. He believes he cannot perform well on grass. Despite winning the Australian Open, Safin acknowledges his desire to win more Grand Slam titles, but needs to improve. 
He had doubts about winning another major after losing the Australian Open finals and facing pressure in his matches against Lleyton Hewitt.  Safin expressed relief at achieving victory.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Marat Safin is declining his chances of winning Wimbledon after losing at the Australian Open and feeling discouraged about playing on grass surfaces. He is hopeful for more Grand Slams despite this. He has worked hard to win two Australian Opens in a row but acknowledges that he cannot play on clay or hard courts, so he is focusing on more challenging court conditions. He is also considering working with Peter Lundgren after Sampras' retirement and hopes to make another Grand Slam title at the 2023 French Open.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Marat Safin, after losing to Lleyton Hewitt in the first set at Wimbledon, expresses doubts about winning another Grand Slam title and says he will play with no expectations. He hopes winning the Australian Open will boost his confidence towards more Grand Slams. Safin is considering working with coach Peter Lundgren for a bit longer as part of his comeback plan.
qwen2.5:3b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon again after his loss last year. He feels unable to play on grass courts due to his preference for other surfaces. While he acknowledges his second Grand Slam title at the Australian Open gives him renewed belief in winning more, Safin remains uncertain about his ability to win further Grand Slams, citing past losses and a lack of self-confidence as factors. However, he is optimistic with the support from coach Peter Lundgren.
opencoder:1.5b: Safin plays down Wimbledon hopes after losing the Australian Open. After the first final that he didn't win against Thomas Johansson, he couldn't see himself winning the Grand Slams anymore. He is hopeful that winning a couple more can give him the belief he needs to win more Grand Slam titles.
smollm:1.7b: Safin plays down Wimbledon hopes by saying he gave up playing on clay after losing in round one last year and now he is hopeful that winning the Australian Open will give him the belief he needs to win more Grand Slam titles. He said he was once confident in his ability to win the 2000 US Open but then lost in two Australian Open finals. After losing in round one last year, Safin said he began to doubt himself again and started to think about giving up on Wimbledon altogether. However, after losing in round one last year, Safin said he was more confident than ever before and believed that winning the Australian Open would give him the belief he needed to win more Grand Slam titles.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Marat Safin's thoughts on winning Grand Slam titles. The user provided a detailed summary already, but I'm supposed to come up with my own concise version without any explanations or formatting. Let me break down what each part is saying.

First, the main point is that Safin has ruled out playing in Wimbledon again because he lost last year's match. He admitted he doesn't plan on winning any future Grand Slam titles after losing in round one. That’s his stance on tennis.

Then, there are some quotes where he talks about not having expectations when facing clay courts, which makes sense since he plays on hard surfaces. He mentions that while he won two major tournaments (Australian Open and US Open), it was unexpected for him to win another Grand Slam. That's a bit of a shift from his previous achievements.

He also talks about his past experiences with other titles. For instance, in the US Open 2000, he didn't face any pressure because Sampras was the favorite. But when he lost that set against Hewitt, he started doubting himself again. He realized that losing a set makes him question if he can continue winning, especially on clay courts.

He says after the US Open, he felt better because he had to handle more pressure. In other tournaments, like the French Open, he once was in the semi-finals but didn't believe he could win it. So he realized he needed to be more confident and open to improve.

In summary, Safin is trying to rebuild his confidence after losing two top tournaments. He lost some matches on clay, which gave him a chance to start doubting himself again. After that loss, he felt a bit better about continuing to play at Wimbledon.
</think>

tinyllama:1.1b: In an interview with Australian media outlet The Daily Telegraph, World No. 1 tennis player Marat Safin has discussed his future aspirations and his thoughts on the possibility of winning the Australian Open. Safin revealed that he had "given up" on the tournament and is looking forward to other Grand Slam titles in the future. Despite losing the first set against Lleyton Heath in Sunday's final, Safin believes that winning another major title is still within his reach.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon, but believes he can improve his chances if he continues to play on grass. The 25-year-old remains undefeated in his career against his former mentor Peter Lundgren but has played with little expectation since breaking through as a teenager in 2000.
